definitions: looking carefully and thoroughly for something or someone
examining deeply and thoroughly, especially in questioning or analysis
examples: The detective made searching inquiries about the suspect
She spent hours in searching exploration of the archives
He gave her a searching look that seemed to see through her
The committee conducted a searching examination of the evidence

definitions: burning with extreme heat that scorches or chars surfaces
causing intense sharp pain, either physical or emotional
extremely harsh and critical in judgment or expression
examples: The searing heat from the fire forced them back
She placed the meat on the searing hot grill
He felt searing pain shoot through his injured leg
The searing memory of betrayal haunted her for years
The journalist wrote a searing critique of the policy
Her searing indictment of corruption shocked the public

definitions: relating to or characteristic of a particular season of the year
happening or available only at certain times of the year
employed only during particular times or busy periods
examples: The restaurant offers seasonal menus featuring local produce
Seasonal changes affect wildlife migration patterns
Strawberries are seasonal fruits available in early summer
The store stocks seasonal decorations for each holiday
They hired seasonal workers for the Christmas rush
Many students take seasonal jobs during summer break

definitions: having much experience and skill through long practice in a field
enhanced with herbs, spices, or other flavorings for taste
treated or aged to improve strength, durability, or performance
examples: The seasoned detective quickly solved the complex case
She's a seasoned traveler who knows Europe well
The chef prepared perfectly seasoned grilled vegetables
This seasoned chicken has a wonderful blend of herbs
The seasoned wood burns better in the fireplace
Use seasoned cast iron for the best cooking results

definitions: in a sitting position or placed on a seat
equipped with a specified number or type of seats
firmly fixed or established in a particular position
examples: The seated guests waited for dinner to be served
Please remain seated until the plane stops completely
The six-seated dining table fits perfectly in the room
They bought a seven-seated SUV for their large family
The firmly seated valve prevents any leakage
Make sure the component is properly seated before testing

definitions: moving or directed toward the sea from the land
positioned to face or look toward the sea
examples: The seaward current carried the boat out to deeper water
Birds flew in a seaward direction as evening approached
The seaward windows offer spectacular ocean views
They built their house on the seaward side of the hill

definitions: in good enough condition to sail safely on the sea
examples: The inspector certified the vessel as seaworthy
Only seaworthy boats are allowed to leave the harbor
After repairs, the ship was finally seaworthy again
The old fishing boat was barely seaworthy

definitions: of wine, especially champagne, that is dry rather than sweet
examples: She prefers sec champagne to the sweeter varieties
The waiter recommended a sec white wine with the fish
This sec sparkling wine pairs perfectly with oysters
They served a crisp sec at the reception

definitions: sheltered or screened from general activity, view, or company; private and quiet
examples: They found a secluded beach away from the tourists
The secluded cabin offered perfect solitude for writing
She preferred the secluded corner table in the restaurant
The secluded garden provided a peaceful retreat

definitions: coming immediately after the first in order, rank, or importance
constituting an additional one of the same kind; another
of inferior quality or lesser importance than the best
examples: She finished in second place in the marathon
This is my second attempt at the recipe
I'll have a second helping of dessert, please
He bought a second car for his wife
They sell second quality goods at reduced prices
These are second grade materials, not premium ones

definitions: of lesser importance, rank, or value than something primary
derived from or dependent on something original or primary
relating to education for children from age eleven to sixteen or eighteen
examples: Cost is a secondary consideration after safety
These are secondary issues we'll address later
The secondary infection developed after the initial illness
Secondary sources interpret primary historical documents
She teaches at a secondary school in London
Secondary education prepares students for university

definitions: having been owned or used by someone else before; not new
received from or through an intermediary rather than directly experienced
examples: She bought a secondhand car to save money
The secondhand bookstore has rare first editions
I heard the news secondhand from a colleague
His secondhand account of events proved unreliable

definitions: kept hidden from others' knowledge or view; concealed deliberately
known only to a limited number of people; confidential
examples: They met at a secret location known only to them
She kept a secret diary under her mattress
The secret documents were locked in the safe
He shared secret information with the journalist

definitions: relating to the work or skills of a secretary or administrative assistant
examples: She has excellent secretarial skills including typing and filing
The company offers secretarial training programs
He performs secretarial duties for the executive team
They hired a secretarial service for the conference

definitions: inclined to conceal feelings, intentions, or information from others
examples: He's very secretive about his personal life
The secretive organization rarely releases information
She became increasingly secretive after the incident
Their secretive behavior aroused suspicion

definitions: relating to religious or political sects and their differences
rigidly adhering to a particular sect or party; showing prejudice
examples: Sectarian violence erupted between the religious groups
The region has a long history of sectarian conflict
His sectarian views prevented meaningful dialogue
They rejected sectarian politics in favor of unity

definitions: relating to a distinct part or subdivision of something larger
made up of separate sections that can be assembled or rearranged
concerned with or representing the interests of a particular group or region
examples: The sectional map shows different areas of the city
They studied sectional views of the building design
We bought a sectional sofa for the living room
The sectional bookcase can be reconfigured easily
Sectional interests threatened national unity
The party must overcome sectional differences

definitions: divided or arranged into distinct parts or segments
legally detained in a psychiatric hospital for compulsory treatment
examples: The sectioned report made it easy to find information
The sectioned orange was arranged on the plate
He was sectioned after the mental health assessment
Being sectioned requires approval from medical professionals

definitions: not connected with religious or spiritual matters; worldly
occurring over a long period of time, especially centuries
examples: France maintains a secular government separate from religion
They attend a secular school rather than a religious one
The secular decline in interest rates continued
Scientists study secular changes in climate patterns

definitions: protected against danger, damage, or unwanted access; safe
firmly fastened or fixed in position; not likely to move
feeling safe, stable, and confident; free from fear or anxiety
examples: The secure facility houses sensitive documents
Online banking requires a secure internet connection
Make sure the ladder is secure before climbing
The cargo must be secure before we depart
She feels secure in her relationship
Children need secure attachment to develop well

definitions: calm, dignified, and unhurried in manner or behavior
under the influence of sedative drugs; medically calmed
examples: The sedate pace of life in the countryside suits her
He maintained a sedate manner despite the chaos
The patient was sedate after receiving medication
The sedate animals were easier to examine

definitions: tending to calm or soothe; having a tranquilizing effect
examples: The sedative effect of the medication helped her sleep
Chamomile tea has mild sedative properties
The doctor prescribed sedative drugs for anxiety
Music can have a sedative influence on patients

definitions: characterized by much sitting and little physical activity or exercise
examples: A sedentary lifestyle increases health risks significantly
Office workers often have sedentary jobs
Sedentary behavior contributes to obesity and heart disease
She changed from a sedentary to an active routine

definitions: relating to rocks formed by the deposition and compression of sediment
examples: Limestone is a common sedimentary rock formation
Sedimentary layers reveal Earth's geological history
The sedimentary deposits contain ancient fossils
Geologists study sedimentary structures for oil exploration

definitions: inciting or causing people to rebel against government authority
examples: The government banned seditious publications during wartime
He was arrested for making seditious statements
The seditious movement gained support among workers
Authorities monitored seditious activities closely

definitions: attractive in a way that tempts one sexually or romantically
tempting and attractive in a way that may lead to unwise choices
examples: Her seductive smile caught his attention immediately
The seductive dress enhanced her natural beauty
The seductive offer of easy money proved dangerous
The seductive appeal of fame can be misleading

definitions: containing seeds; having seeds present or added
given a ranking or position in a tournament based on ability
examples: She prefers seeded grapes for making jam
The seeded bread has a nice texture
The seeded players advanced to the quarterfinals
As a seeded team, they avoided early elimination

definitions: sordid, shabby, and potentially connected with illegal activities
containing or covered with many seeds
looking or feeling slightly ill or unwell
examples: The detective entered the seedy bar downtown
They stayed in a seedy motel by the highway
The seedy raspberry jam has an interesting texture
These seedy crackers are full of nutrients
He looked rather seedy after the long night
She felt seedy and decided to stay home

definitions: taking into account the fact that; considering
examples: Seeing the weather forecast, we canceled the picnic
It's remarkable progress, seeing how recently she started
Seeing that you're here, you might as well help
The price is reasonable, seeing the quality offered

definitions: appearing to be real or true but not necessarily so
examples: His seeming indifference masked deep concern
The seeming contradiction puzzled the researchers
Despite seeming calm, she was extremely nervous
The seeming simplicity of the solution was deceptive

definitions: flowing or leaking slowly through porous material or small openings
examples: Seeping water damaged the basement walls
The seeping wound required immediate medical attention
Oil was seeping through cracks in the pipeline
Seeping moisture created mold problems

definitions: bubbling or churning as if boiling; in violent agitation
filled with intense but unexpressed anger
examples: The seething volcanic crater threatened to erupt
A seething mass of insects covered the ground
She was seething with rage after the betrayal
His seething resentment finally exploded

definitions: relating to or consisting of segments or distinct parts
examples: The segmental analysis revealed structural patterns
Segmental arch bridges are common in historic architecture
The company uses segmental reporting for each division
Linguists study segmental features of speech sounds

definitions: divided into or composed of distinct segments or sections
examples: The segmented worm moved through the soil
A segmented marketing approach targets different groups
The segmented display shows individual characters
Their segmented training program has four phases

definitions: separated or isolated based on race, religion, or ethnic group
separated or set apart from others or from the main group
examples: The segregated schools were declared unconstitutional
They protested against segregated public facilities
The segregated waste bins help with recycling
Patients are segregated based on infection risk

definitions: relating to earthquakes or earth vibrations
having an extremely significant or widespread effect
examples: Seismic activity increased before the volcanic eruption
The building meets strict seismic safety standards
The election results caused a seismic shift in politics
It was a seismic moment in the company's history

definitions: carefully chosen as being the best or most suitable
used by or consisting of a small, exclusive group
examples: Only select students were invited to the program
The chef uses select ingredients for special dishes
The select committee will investigate the matter
It's a select club with limited membership

definitions: chosen from a number of alternatives; picked out as preferred
examples: The selected candidates will be interviewed next week
Selected works from the collection are on display
She read from selected passages of the novel
Only selected stores carry this product line

definitions: careful in choosing; tending to choose only certain things
affecting or acting on only some things and not others
examples: She's very selective about which projects she accepts
The university has highly selective admission standards
This herbicide is selective and won't harm grass
The drug has selective action on cancer cells

definitions: of or relating to oneself or itself
examples: Self preservation is a basic human instinct
She practices self care through meditation
The self checkout lanes speed up shopping
He's writing a self help book

definitions: lacking consideration for others; concerned chiefly with one's own profit or pleasure
examples: His selfish behavior hurt everyone around him
It was selfish to take the last piece
She made a selfish decision without consulting anyone
Selfish motives drove his charitable donations

definitions: having or showing more concern for others than for oneself; unselfish
examples: Her selfless dedication to charity inspired many
The nurse showed selfless compassion to patients
His selfless act saved three lives
Parents often make selfless sacrifices for children

definitions: relating to meaning in language or the study of meanings
examples: The semantic analysis revealed subtle differences
Semantic errors occur when words are misunderstood
They studied the semantic properties of verbs
Semantic web technology improves data organization

definitions: having light rainfall; drier than humid but not completely arid
examples: Semiarid regions support grasslands and sparse vegetation
The semiarid climate requires drought-resistant crops
Much of the western plains have semiarid conditions
Semiarid zones face increasing desertification risks

definitions: partially automatic, requiring some human control but performing some functions automatically
examples: The semiautomatic rifle fires one round per trigger pull
She drives a semiautomatic transmission vehicle
The semiautomatic washing machine needs manual water filling
They use semiautomatic welding equipment

definitions: having the shape or form of half a circle
examples: The semicircular arch topped the ancient doorway
They sat in a semicircular arrangement around the speaker
The semicircular canal helps maintain balance
A semicircular driveway led to the mansion

definitions: strongly influencing later developments; containing creative or original ideas
relating to or containing semen or seed
examples: Darwin's seminal work changed biological science forever
It was a seminal moment in civil rights history
The seminal fluid analysis showed normal results
Seminal vesicles produce components of semen

definitions: relating to or befitting a senator or senate
examples: The senatorial election attracted national attention
She has a senatorial bearing and speaking style
Senatorial committees oversee government departments
The senatorial race became increasingly competitive

definitions: showing the weaknesses or diseases of old age, especially mental decline
examples: His senile behavior worried his family members
The senile patient required constant care
Senile dementia affects millions of elderly people
She showed senile confusion and memory loss

definitions: having a higher rank, status, or position than others
older in age or longer in service than another person
in the final year of high school or college
examples: The senior manager oversees three departments
She holds a senior position in the company
He's senior to me by five years
The senior citizens receive special discounts
Senior students are preparing for graduation
The senior class organized the prom
